tag: html body text div table tbody tr td ul li a span

content: Canada Post’s computerized systems can decipher a wide range of addressing styles – from handwritten notation to typed and printed labels, but studies show that a consistent approach to mail addressing leads to more efficient handling. For Canada Post’s Customers, large and small, this translates into better service and lower costs. Consistent and accurate addressing eliminates the need for extra handling or redelivery by Canada Post. Standardized addressing ensures that mail is consistently “delivered on time, the first time, every time.”

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: The guidelines in this chapter promote the most technologically efficient formats for addressing. It does not limit mailers to any one format. In some cases, because of individual preference or other considerations, mailers may not be able to follow the formats that this Guide presents.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: For more technical information on the physical characteristics necessary for effective processing by Canada Post’s automated systems,

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p a span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
html body text div table tbody tr td p a span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Addresses should be written in upper case; however, mailers may wish to use lower case due to individual preference or other considerations.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Postal codes should be printed in upper case with the first three elements separated from the last three by one space (no hyphens). If the postal code is not formatted in this manner, the mail may be delayed.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: The municipality, province or territory, and postal code should always appear on the same line. There should be one space between the municipality, province or territory and two spaces between the province or territory and postal code.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Characters in the address block should not be underlined.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Punctuation should not be used unless it is part of a proper name, (ST. JOHN'S). However, mailers may wish to use punctuation due to individual preference or other considerations.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Accents may be used as they are an integral part of language but they are not considered to be punctuation.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: The # symbol should never be used, nor the French equivalent no as part of the address.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: All lines of an address should be formatted with a uniform left margin and should be less than 40 characters per line, excluding spaces.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Space between address lines should be at least 0.5 mm but no more than one blank line between lines of addressing.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: All characters should be larger than 2 mm and smaller than 5 mm from the top to bottom (10 to 12-point). Return addresses may use smaller characters and should not be larger than the destination address.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Only non-proportional fonts (characters which occupy the same width) should be used. The following are examples of acceptable fonts: OCR B, Letter Gothic, Elite, Lotus Line-Draw, MS Line Draw, Courier, Courier New, Pica and Copy Pica.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Return addresses should be formatted in the same fashion as the destination address, and located in the top-left corner of the mail piece, clearly separated from the destination address, or on the back of the mail piece at the top. The return address is mandatory on Priority Courier, Xpresspost, Expedited Parcel and Regular Parcel items.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td span
content: Canada Post encourages all mailers to respect the wishes of Customers in matters of format. These guidelines have taken care to accommodate the requirements of the English and French languages by recognizing and accepting the use of upper- and lower- case characters, including accents, as well as the full spelling of and punctuation between addressing elements.

content: The postal code is an integral part of every postal address in Canada. The postal code was designed to aid in sorting mail by both mechanized and manual methods. It also enables the Customer to presort mail, thereby bypassing a number of sorting processes within Canada Post and reducing costs.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: The Structure of the Postal Code

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: The postal code is a six-character uniformly structured, alphanumeric code in the form “ANA NAN” where “A” represents an alphabetic character and “N” represents a numeric character. A postal code is made up of two segments: “forward sortation area” and “local delivery unit.”

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: The forward sortation area is a combination of three characters (alpha-numeric-alpha). It identifies a major geographic area in an urban or a rural location.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: The local delivery unit is a combination of three characters (numeric-alpha-numeric). It identifies the smallest delivery unit within a forward sortation area.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: Forward Sortation Area – The First Segment of the Postal Code

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: The “forward sortation area” or “FSA” represents a specific area within a major geographic region or province. The forward sortation area provides the basis for the primary sorting of forward mail.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
html body text div table tbody tr td p b span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: of the forward sortation area segment identifies one of the 18 major geographic areas, provinces or districts:

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
html body text div table tbody tr td p b span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: of the forward sortation area is an important component of mail preparation as it identifies either:

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: an urban postal code: numerals 1 to 9 (E

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td ul li u span
html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: J). Urban postal codes are generally serviced by Letter Carrier or community mailboxes; or

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
html body text div table tbody tr td ul li u span
html body text div table tbody tr td ul li span
content: A). Rural postal codes are serviced by rural route drivers and/or postal outlets.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
html body text div table tbody tr td p b span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: of the forward sortation area segment (E2

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p u span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: ) in conjunction with the first two characters, describes an exact area of a city or town or other geographic area.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: Local Delivery Unit – The Second Segment of the Postal Code

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: The “local delivery unit” or “LDU”, identified by the last three characters of the postal code, allows for a more final sort within a forward sortation area.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
html body text div table tbody tr td p b span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: , the last three characters may indicate a specific city block (one side of a street between two intersecting streets), a single building or, in some cases, a large-volume mail receiver.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
html body text div table tbody tr td p b span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: , the last three characters, together with the forward sortation area, identify a specific rural community.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: Canada Post’s postal code address data is used to determine or verify the correct postal code for an address anywhere in Canada or identify the complete range of addresses that correspond to any one postal code. The data is available by download from a secured Canada Post FTP site, on CD-ROM or IBM cartridge, and is updated and distributed monthly.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: Delivery Mode data, Householder and Householder-Plus data are also available. Additional information on postal code data is available at :

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: Free postal code lookup is available to Customers through Canada Post’s website at: «

content: Postal codes can also be obtained by calling 1-900-565-2633 for service in English or 1-900-565-2634 for service in French.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span

html body text div table tbody tr td p a span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: Address Accuracy is a program designed to improve delivery by encouraging Customers to accurately address mail. Every item must be addressed to a specific individual or company. In the case of Addressed Admail and Catalogue Mail, items may also be addressed to a non-personalized descriptor, such as "Occupant" or similar wording. Every item must display a complete mailing address including any required suite or unit information as well as the valid postal code for that address. If the mailing address is not complete, the mail may be delayed or returned.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: Consistent and accurate addressing eliminates the need for extra handling and/or redelivery. For Customers, this translates into a more efficient service and lower costs. Accurate addressing helps ensure the mail is delivered on time, every time.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: Participation in the Address Accuracy Program is mandatory for all Machineable, Letter Carrier Presort (LCP), and NDG Presort mailings greater than 5,000 items.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: The standard for Address Accuracy is 95%. This means that 95% of the addresses on the Customer's database are determined to be valid. This is done by using a Canada Post recognized address validation and/or address validation and correction software. If the percentage on the

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p i span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: (SOA) produced by the software is less than 95%, an adjustment will be applied to the mailing.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: Customers must record their Address Accuracy percentage and expiry date obtained from their

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p i span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
html body text div table tbody tr td p i span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
html body text div table tbody tr td p i span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: ). Failure to record the Address Accuracy percentage and expiry date on the

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p i span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
html body text div table tbody tr td p i span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: ) will result in the application of a surcharge.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: Customers are requested to keep a valid copy of the

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p i span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: (SOA) on file in the event that Canada Post requests a copy.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: In the case of Incentive Lettermail, Address Accuracy applies to Low Density Presort and Machineable mailings greater than 5,000 items, as well as to High Density Presort mailings greater than 500 items deposited in a Letter Carrier office. Customers who deposit Short and Long (S/L) High Density Presort mail in non-letter carrier offices (not serviced by letter carriers) for delivery within that same office, are exempt from the Address Accuracy requirements. All other requirements to access the High Density Presort service option must be adhered to.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: More information on the Address Accuracy Program can be found in the

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p i span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: , on the Canada Post website at

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td p a span
html body text div table tbody tr td p span
content: or from a Canada Post Representative.
